Then slip spraii away from-the fence and run up the- road, a hundred fears taking possession of her bosom. But Zeb was gone. Oh. why tiki he go? Why did lie not wait Just a moment longer? She quickeucd h r pace and when she reached the top of the hill was almost out of breath. Zeb had gone out of sight down the mountain. She tried to call his name, but her utterance was only a whisper. But at last she managed to call Oh, Zeb!  The breeze blew the echo of her own tones back into her face. Tears gushed from her eyes, and she sunk down upon the roadside to sob away her sudden lieartsickhess. Tile clouds begun to gatlln nml at nfidnight the rain began to fail in tor rents. Uy dawn the waters of the Tuckasicge were high between its banks, and the boom-loggers were busy with their rafts, but Zeb Norton, their farmer foreman-, was not among them. Six years had slippel away. Nance Hooper still lived with her father in the cabin on the side of the mountain. She ktiJ! went outeach evening to call the lings at Ik head of the ravine, nml ii her heart she still lived the old love and deep Zeb Norton has never been heard or Sineo his, sudden disap pearance. Gold had been discovered on theiTuckasieBo, and. the. community was wild with excitement. But what saemfed unfortunate to the prospectors was that the rich vein had been dis covered ou a body of land belonging to one Zeb Norton, whose whereabouts were unknown. They feared to pro ceed with mining operations without having first having secured a lease of some kind, and since this could not he obtained from the owner the enterprise was at a standstill. Half a year passed by. One day n passenger stepped from the morning train which stopped at Dollsboro, niul stood with his hands rammed down into pockets. He was dressed in the style of a Westerner. A wide-brimmed sombrero rested on his head, nud a heavy brown mustache ornamented bis upper lip. For a moment he gazed all around him.  Its not exactly like it used to be. though it aint much changed, either. he muttered, as he picked up his valise and walked toward a little boarding house a few yards away. It was noon, nud Ihe traveler was hungry. Meet ing the landlady at Ihe entrance, he gave her a fitly-rent piece and asked 11 the way to the dining room. After dining the stranger spent sev eral hours in wandering about the vtl- ige. Late In the afternoon lie sus pended his valise on a stout staff which he rested on his shoulder and set off up the river road afoot. Ever and raon, as he tramped along the high way he would stop at some high point and gaze across the hills and valleys. Just like they used to he, all just the same, he would usually mutter as he turned away and continued his journey. At Inst he reached the highest point in the road where it turned dowu the mountain oh the other side of the river. Just the same, he said, theres not even a change in the road. Wonder if Mark Hooper lives there yet, lie contiued as lie,looked toward the cabin off to the right. A little farther aloug he turned away from the road and walked slowly dowu to where the fence crossed the ravine. Here he seated himself ou an old. fast- deeaying stump, allowiug the staff and valise to carelessly slip from his shoulders. Then, pushing his sombrero hack upon his head he locked his fingers across his knee and gazed away through the opening over the ravine. It was almost sundown and there were a few clouds in the sky. Just the same, he muttered again after a few monseuts silence every thing just like it was. I wonder if Nance did ----  He closed his lips tightly against further utterance. There seemed to be a sudden breaking loose of somethin which had been long tied up in hi breast. At last he arose, and, shoulderiuj his staff and valise, started back to the road. And just as he turned his bar toward the cabin Nance came out with her apron full of vegetables for the hogs, and came on slowly down the path toward the fence. The traveler, who had walked on without looking backward, had scarce ly disappeared beyond a turn in the road, when his ears caught the sounds  Pig-pig-pig-oo-eh. as Nance called the hogs. Again tlie staff and valise slipped from his shoulder, and, with his bands rammed down into his pockets, he listened, while his heart beat heavily against his breast. At last he turned about and slowly retraced his steps, leaving his bag gage, where it had fallen, in the middle of the road. He approached within a few feet of Nance before he stopped. Then, steadying his voice as well as he could, be called her name. Nance suddenly turned about gazed upon the tall form of the West erner. document.text: Zarzas Fine Reduced. Newport News.Joseph J. Zarza, clerk in the Cuban Consulate here, who was fined 500 and sentenced to three months in jail in the police court for assault on Mrs. Charles F. Brown, wife of a shipyard draftsman, was found guilty by a jury in the Corpora tion Court .on his appeal from the lower tribunal, but the jury reduced the punishment to a fine of 5 and costs. Five of the seven jurors stood for acquittal, It is said, and the 5 fine was a compromise.

document.text: Your Christm as tree and the decorations on it are fire haz ards which you will w ant to j watch m ost carefully this Christ-  m as. R em em ber when you I bring a tree into your house it j is going to dry up. A fresh cut j tree will not take fire any m ore  easily during the first day or two J than would the evergreen shrubs  growing outside but it becomes j a m ore serious fire hazard every hour. At the end of a week, it will be highly flammable. It is best to bring in a fresh tree as short a time before Christmas as possible, and to remove it as soon afterwards as you can. If you do this, ordinary precautions should prevent it from taking fire. Fami lies, clubs, churches and business men who want to keep their trees from a week or more before Christ mas until after New Years day need observe special safeguards to keep it reasonably safe. P lace in Pan of W ater. The tree can be kept fresh if you set it up in a pan of water. Cut off the base of the tree at an angle at least one inch above the original cut and keep it standing in water during the entire period that the tree is in the house, adding water to the jar or tub in which the tree stands at intervals to keep the wa ter level always above the cut. This methed when used with fresh trees reduces the flammability as effec tively as any fireproofing chemicals. Chemicals may cause the tree to turn brown or yellow or to lose its needles. The place you select for your tree should be well away from stoves, ra diators, and other sources of heat. The tree should be well secured against falling by inconspicuous wires holding it against the wall. The tree should be so placed that standing qr fallen, it cannot block a doorway which might be needed to escape from the room. Candle Still Takes Toll. The candle for Christmas is still taking its yearly toll of lives and property. It is found on Christmas trees more rarely every year, but none the less, it is used unwisely in many places during the Christmas n . j  season. document.text: young lady, all unconscious.. of ...the honor which was about to befall her, reading a six-hundred-page critique of Chopins music, and calmly munching chocolatesout of a basket decorated with eight shades of silk roses. - Sit down and have a chocolate, Aunt Helen, hospitably offered Gail, slipping a marker in her book. Mrs. Davies consumed a great deal of time in selecting a chocolate, but she did not sit down.  Shall you be at liberty this evening. Gail? she inquired, with much care lessness. Why? and Gail, whose feet were stretched out and crossed, in lazy ease, looked up at her sunt sidewise from under her curving lashes. Mrs. Davies hesitated a moment. Houston Van Ploon would like t 1 call. Are they still downstairs?. Gail suddenly unveiled her eyes, and brought her slippers squarely in front of her divan. Also she sat bolt up right. Yes, and Mrs. Dayies betrayed signs of nervousness, Are they making the appointment forH ouston? Yes. The word drawled. Why? and Gails brown eyes be gan to crackle. Mrs. Davies thought it better to sit down. My dear, a great honor has come to you.. . . Gail leaned forward towards her aunt, and tilted her chin. Houston wants to propose, and hes sent his father and sister to find out if he may! she charged. Yes, acknowledged Mrs. Davies, driven past the possibility of delay or preparation, and feeling herself unjust ly on the defensive. I shall not be at home this eve ning. announced Gall decisively, and stretched out her feet again, and crossed her little gray slippers, and took a chocolate. Or any other eve ning, she added. Mrs. Davies lost her flutter imme diately. This was too stupendously serious a matter to be weakly treated. My dear, you dont understand! she protested, not in anger, but In pa tient reason. Houston Van Ploon has been the unattainable match of New York. He is a gentleman in every par ticular, a desirable young man in every respect, and gifted with everything a young girl would want He has so much money that you could buy a kingdom and be a queen, if you chose to amuse yourself that way. He has a dignified old family, which makes mere social position seem like an ignomini ous scramble for cotillion favors and it is universally admitted that he is the most perfect of all the Van Ploons for many generations. Not exception ally clever but that Is one of the rea sons the Van Ploons are so particular to find a suitable matrimonial alliance for him. Gail, nibbling daintily at her choco late, closed her eyelids for a second, the long, brown lashes curved down on her cheeks, and from beneath them there escaped a sparkle like the snap of live coals, while the corners of her lips twitched in that little smile which she kept for her own enjoyment.. You cannot appreciate the compli ment which has been paid you, Gail. Every debutante for the past five years has been most carefully consid ered by the Van Ploons, and I sincere ly believe this to be the first time they have unanimonsly agreed on a choice. It is a matter of eugenics, Gail, but in addition to that, Mr. Van Ploon assures me that Houston is most fer vently interested. How careless of them, criticized Gail. They have neither asked for my measurements nor examined my teeth. Gail! Her chaperon and sponsor was both shocked and stern. I positively decline to even discuss the Van Ploon eugenics, stated Gail, pushing aside her chocolates, while a red spot began to appear on her cheeks. I shall not, as I stated be fore, be at home to Houston Van Ploon this eveningor any other evening. I shall not deliver that message, announced Mrs. Davies, setting her lips. As your present sponsor, I shall insist that you take more time to con sider a matter so important. I shall insist on refusing to con sider it for one second, returned Gail quietly. I am very fond of Houston Van Ploon, and I hope to remain so. but I wouldnt marry him under any circumstances. This is firm, flat, and final. Mrs. Helen Davies dropped patient reason instantly. She was aware of an impulsive wish that Gail were in pinafores, and her own child, so she could box her ears, Gail, you compel me to lose my pa tience! she declared. When you came, I strained every influence 1 possessed to have you meet the most desirable eligibles this big city could offer, just as if you were my own daughter! I have succeeded in work ing miracles! I have given you an opportunity to interest the very best! You have interested them, but I have never seen such extravagance in the waste of opportunities! You have re fused men whom thousands in the

The boy and the girl adventurers looked in astonishment at the brown ies with the trays. The trays were be ing brought In for the banquet, and they were growing larger, and the brownies seemed to be growing big ger.  Even the food on the plates and on the trays was growing, too. It was all most mysterious. Grow, grow, grow, the brownies all sang In a sing-song fashion. Grow, grow, grow, so, so, so, for were to have a banquet. In another moment a great gong sounded through the hotel and there was heard a great scurrying. It was then that the boy and the girl looked about them in the hotel. The staircases were great high, wind ing ones, and the floors were of beau tifully polished woodwork, though they could see-some scratches on the floors which looked as though there had been a dance or a ball given there recently. Pictures hung on the walls in enor mous gilt frames, and in the hallway where they stood was the biggest coat and hat rack they had ever seen with so many coats and hats hanging there they felt they could never count them all. The great scurry had kept up. Now the trays had not grown for a flew moments. But they were enormous now, and the brownies were very much larger and the food looked as if it had been prepared for many, many people. Now the hurrying and the scurrying sounded nearer, and from all parts

document.text: yon care to part with the.third? making a desperate effort to appear calm. I have a pupil I should like it for. Oh, well, yes, I dont mind, if yon will fix what yon consider a fair price! Drascovy winced. Ten pounds ? he asked. Yes, if yon judge that to be its worth. He took the violin home to Mrs. Vincent, hut he did not tell her much about it. He went to his room and for the next 34 hoars he never left it. Once they took him some thing to eat, but he sat or stood and played till Mrs. Vinoent was quite vexed only as she said yon never could tell what a genius was going to do next. She supposed he had an inspiration.      My dear M. Drascovy! Gan it be two years since we saw yon in Brigh ton ? Are yoh never coming to see me again ? All my friends are anx ious to congratulate you on yonr late phenomenal successes, so do come and dine with me on Tuesday or any day yon like to name. Now, I shall really take no refusal. By the bye, have you heard of poor Dr. Man- fields sudden deathheart disease ? His daughter is with me now. She was left so very poor, for he was deeply in debt. I shonld like yon to see her. Sincerely yonrs, Mildred Vincent. Conld he meet her, Drascovy thought, the daughter of the man he had defrauded? N o! He wonld refnse, and yet as he sat down to write the note something made him accept. He was not a happy man. Through all his great success, due so largely to that wonderful violin, there had been the skeleton at the feast, and nowthe doctor was dead and his daughter unprovided for, living, it seemed, on charity. . M. DrascovyMiss Manfield ,1 said Mrs. Vincent. She saw a tall, queenly woman, with lustrous brown eyes and bright, fair hair, dressed in a deep black gown, relieved by the least touch of white about the throat. Her move ments were slow and very graceful, and when she spoke it was in a low voice full of melody. She was very beantif nl. He conld hardly take his eyes off her, and yet, if she happened te look toward him, he started and cast down his eyes. He conld not sleep that night. He knew there was only one woman in the world for him and shewas the daughter of the man he had robbed! It was well,or ill, for him that he conld not see her next day, sitting by a conch on which a sick man lay, one hand in his, the other stroking his hair. Patience, dear heart, patience, she whispered, things will be better soon. I shall get introductions and pupils through Mrs. Vincent, and then, dear, it will be all right. You mast be content to wait till then, for you know I shall he always true and loving. .  But it is so hard for you, Nellie I cannot tie you to, a cripple, to life of toil for one so helpless as Oh, it is hard that this shoulc. am. have happened to me, when six months ago I was strong and vigor ous .1 Maybe it is better, dear it should bring us closer together, and in years you may recover, perhaps. Anti now I will read to you, or we will talk together. And so the brave, strong woman helped the man she had loved so long and still lovedven now that he was condemned to lie on a conch for his lifetime through an accident in a London street. He was poor, and so was she. The working and waiting would perse vere and conquer. Drascovy was often to be found at Mrs. Vincenti honse daring the next fortnight, anc one afternoon, to his great delight, he found Mrs. Vincent out and Miss Manfield alone in the drawing room. Ten minntes later he had told her he loved herhad asked her to be his wife. She bid her face in her hands and bade him be silent. You do not understand how shonld yon? she said. I cannot think of what you ask, for if ever marry it will be to some one very different to yourselfto one who

document.text: YOKOHAMA.Marine Pfc. Earl L. Brown. Clarksburg, W. Va., has l confessed robbing a Japanese bank  of 580,000 yen about 38,800 while ! posing as an army bank examiner, 8 th army headquarters announced. The lP vear-old marine is being held here on a larceny charge after he confessed that he planned and conducted the daringly simple theft entirely by himself. His signed confession was taken by criminal investigation division investigators under Capt. Otis J. Carter, Los Angeles, C.alif., who said Brown carried forged papers that enabled him to convince of ficials of the Totsuka branch of the Yokohama-Koshin bank that he was a bank examiner. The confession stated that Brown made a survey of the bank on March 12 and the following day returned and told the bank manager his funds would have to be transferred to Tokyo. The manager placed the 580,000 yen in bags, and Brown, accom panied by four bank clerks who were acting as guards, left for Yokohama by train. At Yokohama they all got off the train and Brown took the mony, got in a waiting truck and drove off, saying he would be back in a few minutes. That was the last the bankers saw of Brown until his ar rest early yesterday morning in a downtown hotel. The truck driver, whose identity was not revealed, was absolved of all connection with the theft after Brown said he offered him 10,000 yen to drive him to Yokosuka with out telling him of the robbery. More than 400,000 yen have been accounted for either ip Browns pos session or in hiding places he point ed out to ariji investigators.

Harrisonburg.In the little hamlet ef Royal Run, Shenandoah county, a mother and her daughter were the brides in a double wedding. Miss B. Annie Smoots was wedded to John M. Pence, of Forestville, while her  mother, Mrs. Sarah C. Smoots, and j Thomas J. Estep, of Cootes Store,  Rockingham county, were married. The ceremony was performed at the j home of the brides mother and grand parents, Mr. and Mrs. Ananias Polk, j Rev, A. K. Beck was the officiating minister. Charlottesville.  The usual fall j meeting of the board of visitors of the University of Virginia was attended by the rector, Armistead C. Gordon, j of Staunton Daniel Harmon, of j Charlottesville W. H. White, of Rich- j mend W. Drewery, of Petersburg J. j K. M. Norton, of Alexandria George I 6. Shackelford, of Orange H. D. j Flood, of Appomattox, and John W. 1 Craddock, of Lynchburg. The visitors accepted the gift by the Peabody Ed- j ucation Board of 40,000 for the erec- j tion of a suitable building for a home j for the department of education. The gift was made on condition that the I university undertake to maintain such j a department at an expenditure of not less than 10,000 a year. President j Alderman and the medical faculty were empowered to make such regu- j latlons as may seem wise on account j of the rapid increase of the first-year i medical class and overtaxed facilities I of the medical laboratory. Five sc hoi- I arshlps carrying exemption from tui-  tion and one-half of the fees In the j academic department were awarded to f the live white high schools In the DSs- j triet of Columbia. Charles G. Maphis, of Charlottesville, was elected profes- sor of secondary education to sue-  ceed Prof. Bruce R. Payne. Petersburg.The quickest criminal trial on record In this State occurred in the Corporation Court, of Peters burg, Friday. Four youthful highway men, ranging in age from 14 to 18 years, Charles C. Williams and James Davis, of Fort Worth, Tex., and Joseph L. Cary and J. L, Brown, of Denver, Col., held up and robbed, at the point of their pistols, Charles C. Brown, ol this city, getting his gold watch arid chain and 80 in money. This occur red Wednesday night. The youths were arrested In Weldon Thursday morning and brought hack at night. Friday morning they pleaded guilty In the police court. At noon they were indicted by the grand Jury, They pleaded guilty, on arraignment, elect ed to be tried by the court, and, In less than an hour had been sentenced, each to 12 years in the penitentiary. The boys bad lived in New York city for two years and left that city for a tour of the South a week ago. They were armed with six pistols and In their possession were found many watches, stickpins and Jewelry, the fruits of heir various robberies. A watch arid a stickpin belonging to Samuel T. Taylor, of Baltimore, who was held up and robbed in that city Sunday night, were recovered. A watch and chain belonging to A. W. Harmon, of Richmond, who was rob bed on Tuesday, were also recovered. Suffolk, Benjamin L. Roberts re signed as treasurer of Isle of Wight county and W. Elliott Lai tie was ap pointed In his stead by Judge iJ. I. White, of the Circuit Court. Mr. Rob erts has filled lhe office for many years and was renominated on the Demo cratic ticket at tlic Hpring primaries, but fulled to have his name on the ticket at, the November election. document.text: Would-Be Do-Gooder Gets Suspended Term for Pains PHOENIX, ARIZ.James Brown was trying only to do a good turn, but the best he got for his trouble was a suspended sentence on a drunkenness charge. Brown, a 41-year-old service sta tion attendant, thought he was do ing the right thing when he drove a citrus truck to police headquar ters for safekeeping after the sta tions parking lot closed. But he did the wrong thing when he staggered up to the police of ficer on duty with the keys to the truck dangling from his fingers. Magistrate C. W. Pensinger sus pended sentence on the drunken ness charge because of Browns good intentions.

Dr. Hykes, of Shanghai, that 93 Protestant missionaries are known to have been killed by the Boxers In China. In a desperate attempt to break prison in New York, Keeper McGovern was killed a trusty was fatally injured, one prisoner was killed and one es caped. By a aeries of explosions in the big medicinal plantof Tarrant  Co.,Green wich and Warren stresta, New York, the surrounding buildings were wreck ed, and hundreds of people were Injur ed, while the number of dead oan be known only when the mass of debris has been removed. The entire lower part of Manhattan was shaken as if by an earthquake. The explosions were Immediately followed by fire of great violence. James Hanna Ford Brown, once chief justice of the West Virginia Su preme Court, died at his home in Charlestown. Clifford Cawthon was killed by his mother in Chattanooga, Tepn., because he was bad and smoked cigarettes. document.text: wore puzzled they thought it might be spinal meningitis but after thorough testing failed to substantiate their suspected diagnosis, they proceeded to test Sarah for other possibilities. Finally the conclusion was reached that Sarah Browning Taylors illness was aborted crib death. She had been striken with crib death, known as the silent killer of infants, and when her mother picked her up the crib death was aborted or in terrupted. It is believed that, had her mother been only one- half minute late in picking up her daughter, the baby would have been dead. From May 31 until July 1, Sarah was dependent on a respirator. There were brief periods when she could breathe without it but not for long she would be dependent on the machine again to keep her alive. It was on June 1 that Sarah was flown by private plane to the Virginia Baptist Hospital in Lynchburg. Before leaving Charleston, the doctors gave the parents and grandparents no hope but Urn Taylors did not share the opinion of the doctors. Looking at Sarah with her beautiful brown eyes and brown hair that has a promise of red highlights, the Taylors love her deeply and have committed her to Gods care and have never stopped hoping. Already walking closely with their Lord the Taylors are aware of a deepening of their faith each day since the onset of Sarahs illness. When Sarah was permitted to leave the hospital, the Taylors were unable to decide whether to take their daughter to their home in Forest or to come to Appomattox County in order to be with his parents. The doctors made the decision for them. Sarah must be kept near the hospital. Sometime earlier Rev. and Mrs. Taylor had purchased a nome in Lynchburg with the idea of retiring there some day  it just so happened that at the time Sarah was leaving the hospital the house was empty. Since the doctors advised the Taylors to have two people with Sarah at all times, Jeff and Debbie moved into this fathers house in Lynchburg and to help them out Rev. and Mrs. Taylor moved from Appomattox Coun ty to the Lynchburg house, also. Jeff, who works at Limitorque and his wife, Debbie, are relieved in the round-the-clock care of Debbie by Grandma and Grandpa. Sarah must be fed every four hours through a tube in her stomach. document.text: Woodmen members from dif ferent areas of the state met in Rocky Mount, Virginia, on Oct. 28th for State Degree Team work. Camp 71 of Appomattox lead by President Harry E. Ranson and Captain Charles L. Crews brought the First Place Trophy home to Appomattox. Camp 71 competed against teams from Roanoke, Staunton, Martins - ville, and Willyesburg, Camp 166 of Roanoke placed second with Camp 167 of Staunton plac ing third. Competition consisted of the ritualistic opening, the closing ceremony, and the ceremony of introduction or initiation. The Uniform Rank judges for the competition were Clyde Brown, Hoyle Brown, and Clay Horner from Tennessee. They judged on team movement, alignment, and manual of arms. Jack Turner and Fred Bennett, of Richmond, were judges on ac curacy in the ritual, correct ness and pronounciation of all w ords. Guy Crewe, national Contd on Page 2

Nine-tenths of all paper is made from wood. At the forest products laboratory at Madison, Wis., of the American Forestry association the mill waste of long-leaf pine has been turned into a brown paper that bos a variety of uses cut into strips, It Is spun into threads and woven into bags, matting, burlap, suitcases and furniture. document.text: Wont You Accept My Humble Apologies? sibility too, no doubt, for there was a quiet self-confidence In her manner which made her, quite unconsciously, a personality among the nondescript humanity that crowded the car. Her hair was light brown, and her eyes. Collins perceived, when she lifted them for a moment In his direction, were his favorite colorat least, at that momentblue-gray. On one side of her sat a swarthy, mean-yisaged Individual, a common Subway type. On the other sat a puffy-faced gentleman, reading his newspaper. Collins took all this in, but his mind was busy with the pros pective interview, and the thought drove away the arrows of the busy little god. Allison was the head of an Important corporation, and the whole of Collins future hinged upon Allisons definition of a clean-cut man. Col lins had totally forgotten the girl by the time the train stopped at Brooklyn bridge. Suddenly his attention was drawn to her by hearing her exclaim in a low, well-modulated voice, but expres sive of intense scorn Will you kindly stop pressing my arm, sir? His nerves were already tingling. This slight incident completely upset his equilibrium. He saw the pufTy- faced man. who had begun to look exceedingly uncomfortable, apparently attempting to conceal himself behind his newspaper.- On the other side of the girl the mean-faced individual was snickering, evidently at her Indigna tion. It Was just a common Subway incident the puffy-faced man was evi dently one of those despicable crea tures who make a practice of molest ing women. Collins leaped forward and dragged the puffy-faced man from his seat. Holding him by the collar with one hand he delivered a clean uppercut with the free fist, and had the satisfaction of landing squarely upon the puffy-faced mans optic. Instantly the car was in an uproar. Collins found himself the center of a mass of struggling humanity. A man was clapping him on the shoulder and shouting approvingly. Well done, young fellow! he exclaimed. Thats tbo way we Southerners would do. Give him what he deserves! Others were straining to get at the puffy- faced man, who, prone on the floor, was endeavoring to shield himself from a rain of kicks and blows. Collins worked himself free and tried to help the girl through the throng. He reached her and offered her his arm. She declined it indig nantly, and Collins, crestfallen, fol lowed her to the car door, where he was at once seized by a gray-coated Subway guard. Hold him! yelled the puffy-faced man, who, hatless and coatless, now appeared on the scene. Even then  Collins noticed with satisfaction that  his eye was nearly closed and sur-1 rounded by a widening circle of black, shading off Into a medley of crimson, magenta, and maroon. Thats the fellow that assaulted and tried to rob me. , Collins saw the girl stop suddenly.

document.text: Women As Member Of Police Force. Richmond. Virginia law enforcement officers, in organization session here in the Coun cil Chamber, City Kail, unanimously adopted a resolution indorsing police women. Ten of the principal cities of the State and -the three largest rail roads were represented in the confer ence. Admiral A. C. Dillingham, director of -public safety of Norfolk, was elected president of the association Major Charles A. -Sherry, Chief of Police ol the Richmond, department, first vice- president J. M. Broughton, chief oi police at Portsmouth, second vice-pres ident Captain G. E. Pollock, of the Richmond force, secretary, and Chief C. B. Borland, of Norfolk, treasurer. Officers of the organization, with the addition of Colonel William M. Myers, Director of Public Safety of Richmond, and Messrs. Thom and Louis Brown- law were appointed a committee to draft for presentation to the next Gen eral Assembly a set of laws regarding the establishment of a uniform set ol identification systems throughout the Commonwealth. This committee will probably present Its report at the next meeting of the organization. Messrs. Sherry, King, Borland, Thom and Pollock were appointed a commit tee to draft the constitution and by laws and decide on a membership fee. It was further agreed to try, to get more hearty co-operation from sheriffs and to promote their interest in the new organization. In a short address at the opening of the session Admiral Dillingham stressed the value of co-operation be tween .police officials in various cities. Mr. Brownlaw declared that the value of women as police officers is exceptional, and that their work could not be replaced by that of -men. ,

Dillingham, director of public safety of Norfolk, was elected president of the association Major Charles A. Sherry, Chief of Police ol the Richmond department, first vice president J. M. Broughton, chief ot police at Portsmouth, second vice-pres ident Captain G. E. Pollock, of the Richmond force, secretary, and Chiel C. B. Borland, of Norfolk, treasurer. Officers of the organization, with the addition of Colonel William M. Myers, Director of Public Safety of Richmond, and Messrs. Thom and Louis Brown- law were appointed a committee to draft for presentation to the next Gen eral Assembly a set of laws regarding the establishment of a uniform set ol identification systems throughout the Commonwealth. This committee will probably present its report at the next meeting of the organization. Messrs. iSherry, King, Borland, Thom and Pollock were appointed a commit- tee to draft the constitution and by laws and decide on a membership fee, It was further agreed to try to get more hearty co-operation from sheriffs and to promote their interest in the new organization. In a short address at the opening ot the session Admiral Dillingham stressed the value of co-operation be tween police officials in various cities, Mr. Brownlaw declared that the value of women as police officers is exceptional, and that their work could not be replaced by that of men.

document.text: Woman Was Never Bitten Or Scratch ed By Dog. Philadelphia.  Although she de Clares that she was never bitten or even scratched by a dog or any other animal, Ellen Brown, 20 years old, is in a critical condition from what physicians have diagnosed as a case of hydrophobia. From early child hood the young woman has had great fear of dogs. Recently her throat became terribly parched, but the sight of water threw her into con vulsions. Her condition rapidly be came worse and today she was said to be dying.

document.text: Woman Hand. Colliers Weekly It is certainly not true that small hands are bred by choice descent, for In one family the hands of both women and men are found different in size and In every other quality. The individual woman of the people stretches and hardens her hand and batters her nails, on her own account, so that months of care would not retrieve it but doubtless her baby hand was much the same as a rich womans in her own babyhood. English women and Americans, with their blonde hands, are admired de liriously for this one beauty by the darker races. But at any rate to Eng lish eyes there is loveliness also In the fine hand that has clear brown color in place of whitea rare beauty, for the blonde woman has usually the finer form of hand but somewhat dark must have been the tender Inward of the hand that played on the virginals of Shakespeare. _____
